From building more affordable housing to expanding paid parental leave, our plan is focused on improving the lives of working families.

The Labor Party's commitment to working Australians is unwavering. We understand the challenges facing families in Holt and beyond, and we are dedicated to delivering meaningful support to improve their lives. From tax relief to job creation, and from wage growth to worker protection, our vision for a fairer and more prosperous Australia is clear. Together, we can build a future where every Australian has the opportunity to thrive and to achieve their aspiration so no-one in this country is left behind.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Help to Buy Bill 2023, Help to Buy (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2023

p.span: Help to Buy Bill 2023
Help to Buy (Consequential Provisions) Bill 2023
Second Reading
Cognate debate.
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Mr THISTLETHWAITE (Kingsford Smith—Assistant Minister for Defence, Assistant Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Assistant Minister for the Republic) (20:01): The Help to Buy Bill 2023 is a really important reform for Australians seeking to buy their first home. We know that there's no more important human right than providing a house and a roof over people's heads—a place for someone to call home, to raise a family and to feel comfort and security—yet too many Australians are being priced out of the housing market in every state and territory across the country. You now see this despair in younger generations of Australians, who have the view that they will never ever be able to afford to get into the housing market. Ten years of neglect from the previous government and the failed ability to come up with a comprehensive housing plan across several states have seen supply dwindle and prices skyrocket. It's left many Australians in despair.

The government is aiming to arrest that decline, to reverse that despair and to provide young Australians, in particular, with hope that they can once again afford to live and to buy a home in the suburbs that they call home. This Help to Buy program is not the sole element but an element of the government's program and policies to make housing more affordable for more Australians and to increase housing supply. This significantly reduces mortgage crisis for eligible low- and middle-income earners by offering savings of up to 40 per cent on purchasing a home. It's designed to address entry-level market challenges by helping to empower Australians to achieve homeownership without inflating prices, and that's the key.

There have been several schemes from Liberal governments—at both the state and territory level—that provide a cash payment to first home buyers, and several studies have demonstrated that the effect of those cash payments is just to pour fuel on the fire. You actually increase demand, and real estate agents and vendors price in on the support that's been given by government. It's made prices worse, and it's made the problem worse. But this plan should ensure that prices aren't artificially increased by unnecessary government support.

This is one element of Labor's comprehensive housing plan that creates a vision to create a more diverse and affordable housing solution for Australians. It's part of our goal, with the state and territories in partnership, to build 1.2 million new homes, demonstrating our commitment to expanding homeownership opportunities. We're prioritising helping more Australians achieve that dream, which should be achievable, of owning their own home.

We recognise the ongoing challenges in the housing sector. Since coming to office, we've supported tens of thousands of Australians to secure safe and secure housing. In 2024, we remain committed to delivering more—more support for home buyers, renters and Australians needing secure accommodation. While recognising the critical situation facing renters, the Help to Buy scheme assists low- and middle-income earners to purchase their first home. To ensure accessibility, income eligibility and property price purchase caps will be implemented, varying by state and region. These caps are designed to support Australians in accessing moderately priced homes aligning with the program's core objective.

Australia's housing challenges are complex, and our government is committed to addressing them comprehensively. So how does the Help to Buy scheme work? It acts as a shared-equity program, providing an equity contribution of up to 40 per cent for new homes and 30 per cent for existing homes. Participants can enter the market with a minimum deposit of just two per cent. The program will run for four years, offering 10,000 places annually. It's a co-investment scheme, where the government co-invests with the budding home purchaser to ensure that the price for purchase is affordable. It will empower Housing Australia to establish these shared-equity arrangements as quickly as possible. This is modelled off a scheme which works in Western Australia called Opening Doors. It's been in place since 2011. It's delivered by their Department of Communities, and it's making homeownership more accessible for low- to middle-income Australians in that state. It's helped tens of thousands of Western Australians own their first home. It's been very successful. It's proven that it works, and this is the scheme that the Albanese government is modelling our scheme on.

Since taking office, we've already supported the construction of 4,937 new homes through Housing Australia. Applications are open for the first round of the Housing Australia Future Fund and the National Housing Accord, and over the next decade we've committed $25 billion in new housing investments. Whilst the states hold primary responsibility for housing policy, the Commonwealth seeks a specific referral power to strengthen the program's administration. It's important to note that the housing experts advise against short-term measures like rent caps and rent freezes, which can have unintended consequences.

We remain committed to ongoing collaboration with all levels of government to achieve better housing outcomes for all Australians. The National Cabinet has committed to a better deal for renters, aiming to harmonise and strengthen renters' rights across Australia. This includes requiring reasonable grounds for eviction, limiting annual rent increases and phasing in minimal rental standards. Additionally, the government delivered the largest increase to Commonwealth rent assistance in over 30 years to support low-income renters. The National Cabinet has also agreed to an ambitious target of building 1.2 million new well-located homes over five years, commencing from 1 July this year. The Commonwealth is providing $3 billion for a new homes bonus, incentivising the states and territories to undertake necessary reforms to achieve this goal.

We have an ambitious agenda to help Australians either get into housing or be able to purchase their own home. This bill is part of a suite of policies that include constructing more affordable housing, constructing more social housing, building a Housing Australia Future Fund, ensuring better rights for renters, partnering with the states to build more homes and having a program such as this that assists Australians to realise that Australian dream of buying their own home—a place that they can call home with security and comfort for their families.

Having listened to a lot of people speak on this, it's unfortunate that the approach of those opposite in relation to this bill is simply that housing is an issue for the states, and this is nothing that the Commonwealth government should be involved in. Housing should be left to the states—it's their issue. Well, that approach over the last decade from the previous coalition government has left us in the mess that we're in at the moment. It's meant that the Commonwealth has been uninterested in ensuring that housing supply kept pace with demand. The states, having failed to meet those demands within their individual jurisdictions, have ensured that demand has increased but supply hasn't, so we've had a housing shortage and a massive increase in prices, to the point where mortgage repayments for the average Australian have now increased by multiples of their annual incomes since the former coalition government came to office. It's no stretch to say that the former coalition government failed Australians when it came to adequately supporting their housing needs.

The Albanese government intends to fix that. We are not going to stand by and say, 'This is an issue for the states.' We are going to get in and get our hands dirty and work to ensure that we build the houses that Australians need—1.2 million of them over the course of the next five years—to ensure that we boost housing supply to ensure that housing is affordable and that Australians can realise the dream of owning their own home. That's exactly what this bill does.

The DEPUTY SPEAKER
( Mr Buchholz ): I give the call to the most honourable member for Calare.

Mr GEE (Calare) (20:11): Thank you, Deputy Speaker, and may I commend you on the outstanding contribution you are making to this House in that role. Australia is in the midst of a housing affordability crisis. Everyone in this House knows it. Every day we hear stories in our electorates of young people and young families being locked out of the residential property market. The pain is very real and governments must respond.

In weighing up whether to support this bill we first have to consider the potential benefits. It's a shared-equity scheme. The government says that the scheme will assist Australians to overcome the hurdle of both saving for a deposit and servicing a mortgage. Participants will only require a minimum two per cent deposit and will benefit from lower ongoing mortgage repayments via smaller home loans. It's said that the scheme could reduce the cost of buying a home by up to 40 per cent.

Against this, concerns with the scheme include that the scheme does not address the current lack of housing supply and that the scheme could contribute to an increase in demand and, therefore, an increase in housing prices. Further, the scheme is capital intensive and ties up capital and is difficult to scale up if successful or, in fact, to be scaled back. There are concerns that the scheme could divert resources from supporting those who are homeless or at risk of homelessness. It's also said that the scheme might encourage some participants to take unnecessary risks that they otherwise would not have taken.

The scheme will apparently create places for 10,000 eligible purchasers every year. How many will be in the Calare electorate? It's difficult to say, but some possibly will be. It's because of this potential benefit to first homebuyers in the Calare electorate and other country communities that I have decided to support this bill. Helping 10,000 eligible purchasers per year is clearly not a silver bullet for the housing affordability crisis, but it will at least help those lucky enough to get a start in the scheme.

Another piece of legislation that can make a positive contribution to easing the housing affordability crisis is the Prohibition on the Purchase of Residential Property by Foreign Entities Bill 2024. It's a private member's bill that I introduced to the parliament during the last sitting period. I introduced this bill because many years ago every single Australian could expect that at some point in their lives they would have the opportunity to own a home or unit and live the great Australian dream, but that dream is slipping away before our very eyes. My bill would ban foreign property spectators from buying homes and units in Australia for two years. Many countries have already introduced such laws, including Canada, New Zealand and Singapore. In Australia, it seems strange that we haven't already done this.

In 2021-22, during COVID, foreign buyers snapped up 4,228 Australian homes and units. Most of these purchases were in the under $1 million price bracket. Since those figures were published, the activities of foreign property speculators have been ramping up big time. The National Australia Bank's recent Residential property survey found that the market share of foreign buyers in new Australian housing markets in October to December 2023 grew for the fifth straight quarter to a 6½-year high of 11 per cent. In New South Wales, foreign buyers had a 15 per cent market share. This points to a near five-fold increase in market share from a low during the COVID pandemic in mid-2021. The NAB survey also found that international agents are reporting an increase in inquiries of over 400 per cent.

We could make thousands of new homes and units available to Australians immediately, without having to take years to build them, by putting a pause on foreign property speculators and giving more Australians their shot at the great Australian dream of home ownership. This is not about turning our backs on the world, but it is about putting the interests of Australians struggling to get into the housing market ahead of the interests of cashed-up foreign property speculators. I would urge all members of this House to support my bill. It now needs to be passed into law.

Ms STANLEY (Werriwa—Government Whip) (20:16): Deputy Speaker, I concur—you are doing a wonderful job. I rise to make a very short contribution on the Help to Buy Bill 2023 as someone who had the benefit of a help-to-buy scheme. My parents were part of the baby boom generation many years ago and, without the government's choices when they decided to buy their house, were probably unlikely to have been ever able to own a home. That made a considerable difference to my family, to my sister and me. It meant I received an education and I am able to stand here as the member for Werriwa. My sister is a doctor. She is an associate professor and has worked in universities for a very long time. I won't share with the House how long because I didn't get her permission to do so! But we ended up with a very stable life, and that is what the Albanese government intends to do with these bills: make sure that people get the opportunity to be able to live the life that they want to live.

It is very important that you have an address. For many jobs, your address means whether or not you get an interview. It means whether or not you might actually be considered for that job long-term. Is it close to transport? Is it where people who actually want to work live? Being able to choose a house and being able to live in those houses is really important. I'm sure many people in this House, and not just on this side of the aisle, had their lives changed because governments made decisions to help to make sure that people got what they deserved and what they were part of. That's what these bills do. I commend these bills to the House. I think we all should consider just what the Australian people deserve and what our government should be providing for them.

Ms DANIEL (Goldstein) (20:19): I spend a lot of time visiting schools in Goldstein and what the schoolkids say to me often sticks in my mind and occasionally disturbs me. At one school visit, for example, one of the children, a year 5 student, approached me to ask about inflation and when I thought it would stop rising. 'My mum and dad are really worried about interest rates, and I'm worried that we might lose our house,' she said.

I was barely out of my teens during the slide into the recession we had to have in the early 1990s, with interest rates at 18 per cent. Times were very tough for my dad as a single parent, who in the end sold the house. Yet in the early 1990s it took the average Australian about seven years to save up for a 20 per cent deposit for a typical dwelling. Now it's almost doubled, to 12 years and rising. Now we have a housing crisis. This is not because of ultra-high interest rates, although the recent increases from the emergency levels of the pandemic are another factor in the stress that many Australians are suffering; this housing crisis has been a long time coming. Simply put, we've not been building enough dwellings to meet demand, and we don't have the skilled workforce or materials to rapidly ramp up supply.

It's broadly acknowledged by eminent economists that first home owner schemes, which have been extended over the years, may be beneficial for the buyers who are fortunate enough to access them but are largely counterproductive in addressing the broader problems of affordability and supply. The evidence is that because they do not address supply and effectively increase demand they act to increase house prices and therefore reduce affordability. The basic facts are well known but warrant repeating.

Help To Buy is the latest instalment in this government's efforts to address the housing crisis. I will support the legislation despite the reservations I have about the bill, just as I supported the Housing Australia Future Fund despite my concerns about its governance provisions and the adequacy of its capital base. It's a decision made on balance—more good than not so good. But what worries me about this legislation is the almost complete absence of specificity. Who will it help? Who'll be prioritised if it's oversubscribed? How will those decisions be made? Will younger people struggling to raise a full deposit be given priority, or will it, for example, be given to older women who are confronting a retirement of poverty because the banks regard it as being too late in their lives for them to qualify for a mortgage? While Help To Buy might do a little to ease the housing crisis for a relatively small number of people, let's be straightforward: it won't fix the problem, which has been a long time coming and which will take short-, medium- and long-term initiatives to fix.

As the Grattan Institute noted in 2022, when Labor unveiled its proposal, while important, shared equity is also no panacea to Australia's broader housing affordability crisis. Nonetheless Grattan, which proposed a similar scheme itself, says that shared equity could help many older Australians into home ownership at a time when home ownership rates are declining, especially for this cohort and the poorer among them.

According to ABS data, just 55 per cent of the poorest 45- to 54-year-olds own their own homes today, down from 71 per cent four decades ago. The problem is particularly acute for women—and not just older women, although they are most likely to find themselves most challenged in keeping a roof over their heads.

A report last year from the Australian Housing and Urban Research Institute details the extent to which women face discrimination and disadvantage in the housing market, specifically that women are less likely to be able to save for a deposit on a home and that those who do manage it take longer to save for a deposit than their male peers. Women are therefore less likely to own a home to support them in retirement. Older women, paying off a mortgage, experience higher levels of stress than their male peers, which affects their health and wellbeing and places further demands on our health systems. Most severely, as housing becomes less affordable, homelessness rates are rising. Older women and women fleeing violence are more vulnerable to homelessness, meaning younger women are overrepresented in homelessness numbers, and older women are the fastest growing group of homeless.

With that in mind, and considering my concerns about the absence of priorities nominated in the legislation for recipients of the benefits of the program, I will be proposing an amendment to the bill that would add a specific reference to women in the object of the legislation. It would also provide a prod to Housing Australia and those in the states and territories responsible for administering the program that they should be cognisant of particular historically disadvantaged cohorts among the low-income individuals that the legislation is designed to assist. I understand that the minister will be reluctant to agree to the amendment, in large measure because of the complexity of negotiating agreements with eight state and territory governments to get this program off the ground. That said, I would ask, then, that reporting on the program is sufficiently comprehensive and detailed to enable us to know for sure and in a timely way that it's assisting the cohorts it aims to help, especially women.

I add here that I know my colleague, the member for Wentworth, will be moving an amendment flagging concern around the lack of a disallowable instrument under this legislation, and that I will also support that amendment.

Grattan applauds the proposal as a positive step forward, particularly in its potential benefits for some older Australians—disproportionately women, who have increasingly been excluded from the housing market. In the 1980s, fully 71 per cent of the poorest 40 per cent of 45 to 54-year-olds were able to own their own home. Now it's down to just 55 per cent, according to the ABS, in part because, as I said earlier, it now takes much longer to put together a deposit.

The Melbourne Institute's HILDA survey found that just 34 per cent of women who separate from their partner and lose the house managed to purchase another home within five years, and only 44 per cent do so within 10 years. For men, the comparable figures are 42 per cent within five years and 55 per cent within 10 years. That's still not great, but better than the predicament confronting their female equivalents. There are other unintended consequences even for those women who retain the family home as part of a separation settlement. I know of women in the Goldstein community who now find themselves struggling to pay the rates, pay for repairs or pay for heating and cooking. In part, the reason for their predicament is down to just two words: stamp duty.

I went to the last election campaigning for an independent, well-funded and adequately resourced review of the tax system, including property taxes. The impact of stamp duty amid what was then an emerging housing crisis was one of the reasons, and, if we're to address the central problems of housing affordability, the issue of stamp duty cannot be avoided.

In my state of Victoria, homeowners and would-be home owners are burdened with the biggest stamp duty take in the country. Analysis by the Melbourne Age shows that the Victorian government raised fully 27 per cent of total state taxes from stamp duty last financial year, compared with a mere 11 per cent in the nineties, and rising above 20 per cent in the early 2000s as property prices took off. According to real estate data analysists PropTrack, the reason is simple: bracket creep. The proportion of Melbourne homebuyers paying the top rate of stamp duty has increased from six per cent in 2008 to 33 per cent today. Homebuyers in Melbourne now need the equivalent of six months of average full-time, post-tax income, or $42½ thousand to cover stamp duty on a median priced home—a sixfold increase since the mid-1980s.

In my electorate of Goldstein, where a median priced home now sells for $2.2 million, stamp duty totals $123,000. No wonder people won't move, even if their kids have left home, they've got bedrooms gathering dust, the house is bigger than they need and they struggle to pay the rates and maintain the property. As eminent economist Chris Richardson puts it: 'Stamp duty is a big red stop sign in front of people where they want to be.' Not only is stamp duty an increasing in barrier to entry for first homebuyers, it is also highly inefficient as well as inequitable, reducing economic activity in Victoria by 55c for every dollar raised—$4.8 billion lost last financial year.

More than a decade ago the review headed by Ken Henry recommended a shift from stamp duty to a broad based annual land tax. A report commissioned by the former New South Wales government made a similar recommendation in 2021, pointing out that, with stamp duty, those who buy and sell property more often pay more tax compared to those who transact less frequently. Its effect is to shift the cost of infrastructure and essential services, like schools, hospitals and roads that everyone benefits from, onto a narrow section of the population, who carry the burden simply because they decide to move house or sell a business more often.

The Henry and New South Wales reports and their recommendations were underpinned by safeguards designed to ensure that homebuyers and homeowners not be penalised in the transition. The New South Wales report recommended offering homebuyers a choice: stick with stamp duty or opt for land tax. There would be transitional costs, and that is where the Commonwealth should come in. As with competition policy in the 1990s and early 2000s, designed to boost productivity—now second only to the cost-of-living crisis as our biggest economic problem—the Commonwealth should reward states that are prepared to make the change with financial assistance to ease the burden on state budgets during the transition.

While previous election commitments, and a degree of PTSD, would deter this government from action on other areas of tax reform—negative gearing and the capital gains tax discounts, for example—the stamp duty/land tax swap is another matter for due consideration in the tax review that we have to have. An opt-in system would make this more politically palatable. Meanwhile, Help to Buy will make some difference at the margins and a relatively small number of deserving individuals will benefit. But we shouldn't kid ourselves that it will make a substantial dent in the housing crisis. That's why I've been urging the government to show a bit of bravery in addressing reform, and beginning a conversation with the state on property taxes would be a good start.

Mr ZAPPIA (Makin) (20:31): Both the coalition and the Greens want to obstruct the Help to Buy Bill 2023, not because it is bad legislation but because it is in their political interest to do so. They both want to ensure that the housing crisis continues right through to the next election and then make it a campaign issue at that time. They are putting politics before people and self-interest before public good.

Housing ownership rates in this country have been falling for decades. In fact, in 2006 homeownership was at around 70 per cent. In 2021 it was down to 67 per cent. Outright ownership—that is, mortgage-free ownership—in 2001 was 38.2 per cent and in 2020 it was 29.5 per cent. The cost of housing today is somewhere between eight and 10 times average household incomes. Housing has never been more out of reach for working Australians. Homelessness has never been worse and public housing waiting times have never been longer.

That's why the Albanese Labor government has made housing a priority policy, with significant funding allocations and a range of policy initiatives that acknowledge that the causes of the housing crisis are many and varied. There is no silver bullet for fixing the housing needs, because there is no single overriding cause. Material shortages, skilled trade shortages, state and local government fees and taxes, interest rate rises, foreign investors, taxation policy and immigration have all, from time to time, been singled out as the cause of today's Australian housing woes. Each of those issues has been identified as a contributing factor, and each of those issues perhaps does play a role within the responses that are required.

However, I want to add to those issues two other matters—firstly, the decline in state government provided public housing. In my own state of South Australia, four decades ago, with a population of around 1.3 million, there were over 60,000 public houses. Today, with a population of 1.8 million, or an increase of 40 per cent over the 1.3 million, there are only 30,000 public homes. If we had maintained the 1980s trend, we should have somewhere around 85,000 public houses, but that is not the case. I suspect that the same figures would apply right across the board to other states.

My second observation is that over recent decades there has been a slide in the number of residents per household, necessitating an increasing number of homes. I note that the member for Goldstein talked about separated families. Family separations are dividing families, duplicating the number of homes required and therefore driving up home prices and housing rents.

This legislation is part of a suite of measures that the Albanese Labor government is backing to make housing available to more people. It will support up to 40,000 households to purchase a home of their own over the next four years under a government backed shared-equity scheme. The government will provide up to 30 per cent of the funding required for existing homes or up to 40 per cent for new homes.

Shared equity is good policy. It gives new homeowners a foot in the door. It gives them an asset, including capital growth, at a price that they can afford with ongoing affordable repayments. When I was Mayor of Salisbury, some two and half decades ago, we initiated a very similar scheme, where the council's contribution to the shared equity was the land itself. From memory, the funding was provided by HomeStart Finance to eligible lower-income applicants. The rest of the scheme was almost identical to what has been proposed here tonight, and I have to say that there was nothing wrong with that scheme whatsoever. Homeownership is good for families and good for society. It's good for families because it provides security and stability. Unlike for renters, the weekly payments go towards securing an asset, which inevitably appreciates in value. Stability and security are what build communities.

I note that those opposite have raised a number of objections to this legislation and asked a number of questions. What happens if the homeowner defaults on their payments? What happens if there are home improvements made—who gets the benefit of that? If the homeowners want to sell, who will be eligible for the funding that has been made available by the federal government? Who sets the price caps? What happens if someone passes away? What are the income limits that will shut people out of the scheme? The questions go on. All of those matters can be addressed; they are not insurmountable. While some members might say, 'I don't see the clear answers in the legislation,' the reality is that what this legislation does is set up a framework. All of the other incidental matters, in one way or another, can be resolved and will be resolved. I'm sure that the minister has already addressed those other issues as part of the package of legislation.

To try and use what I call excuses as to why this legislation might not work is, to me, simply proof of the fact that coalition members and the Greens don't want to support it. Again, that's not because it's not good legislation but because they want to keep this issue alive right through to the next election, when they can campaign on it. The truth of the matter is that this legislation ultimately helps to provide additional housing. The solution to lower house prices and lower rents is, indeed, to increase supply. I think other speakers have made that point time and time again. This legislation increases supply, and the fact is that every other measure that the government has introduced will increase supply. That is exactly what the $10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund does. It's what the $3 billion Social Housing Accelerator payment does, it's what the Home Guarantee Scheme does and it's what this legislation will do—increase supply. When you increase supply, rents will start to come down and the price of housing will start to come down. When that happens, both renting and homeownership become more affordable to people that want to get into the housing market.

We on this side of the House acknowledge that homeownership is important to Australian families. We acknowledge that it is becoming increasingly difficult. We acknowledge that there is no single solution to all the problems, and that's why we have introduced a suite of measures. This is but one of them. I note the comments made by the Leader of the Greens, who spent his whole 15 minutes talking about negative gearing. Not once did he talk about this legislation. Not once did he articulate what is specifically wrong with this legislation, but simply spoke about negative gearing. The debate about negative gearing has been part of the housing conversation in this country for nearly 100 years. In fact, negative gearing was brought in in the 1930s in order to address the shortage of housing at the time. And it's been part and parcel of the Australian psyche and the Australian system ever since. Yes, it was dropped for a couple of years under the Hawke government, but it has been part of the Australian taxation system for nearly 100 years. The problem with the shortage of housing didn't just arise yesterday; it's been in the making over the last two or three decades. It's time that governments finally addressed it. The Albanese government is doing that by the suite of measures that I referred to. This legislation is part of those measures, which will make a difference.

I'll make this last point, because it was a point that was raised by one of the coalition members in their contribution, that there is no take-up in the state schemes. I think they were referring to the New South Wales scheme, where there's a very low take-up. If there's no take-up, then what's your problem with the scheme anyway? The fact that nobody takes it up doesn't make it a bad scheme. In other words, there is no cost to anybody if there's no take-up. So if that's the reason for opposing it, it simply doesn't make sense. The reality is, I believe, that there will be take-up if you make it fair and equitable, and that's exactly what this legislation does.

Dr RYAN (Kooyong) (20:41): I rise to speak on the Help to Buy Bill 2023. We have a housing crisis in this country. Every day that this crisis persists, people's ability to choose the life that they want to live is eroded. It's an unacceptable situation. We all know that there are few things as important as having a place to live—a place to be safe and secure and healthy, and a place to raise, protect and nurture your family. We also know that when a person does not have adequate housing, many aspects of life are that much harder. Being able to secure and maintain a job is very difficult. Enrolling and sending children to school is a challenge. Just being able to adequately prepare food for your family becomes a struggle. Things which many of us take for granted every day are incredibly difficult for those people who do not have secure housing. Housing is a human right, not a privilege.

Homeownership is increasingly out of the reach of younger and less wealthy Australians. More young Australians are continuing to rent well into their 30s and into their 40s. Nearly a quarter of couples who started their family more than five years ago are still renting. Single mothers are now more likely to be in a private rental than not, which is a big change from 20 years ago. People with a disability also face increasing challenges in finding and securing a home. Older women are one of the fastest-growing cohorts now facing homelessness. The Grattan Institute recently predicted that the share of over-65s who own their home will fall from 76 per cent today to 57 per cent by 2056. Today's older renters risk joining tomorrow's renting retirees, nearly half of whom live in poverty. Their numbers will only grow in the future as fewer retirees own their homes. Older Australians who don't own their home when they retire are often doubly punished because they are affected by the aged pension asset test, which ignores housing equity but does capture other savings. Rent assistance paid to pensioners who rent remains woefully inadequate, even after the recent 15 per cent increase.

The frustrating truth is that solutions are available when we have political will to do so. We can see the answer to that when we look at how we were immediately and effectively able to house the homeless during the COVID pandemic, only to turn them back onto the streets once the worst, acute phase of that pandemic passed. There can be no pretence that there are immediate solutions for supplying housing at scale. This is a wicked problem which has had decades to develop. But we do need to attack this problem as a matter of urgency on as many fronts as possible.

This Help to Buy program will help house more than 40,000 people. It will fund 10,000 a year for four years. The Help to Buy Bill 2023 establishes a shared-equity program, addressing the fact that many people looking to buy a home cannot save enough money for their deposit. The program will enable certain low- to middle-income earners to purchase new or existing homes by obtaining an equity contribution from the federal government. That is, the purchaser and the government will effectively be co-owners of the property.

A prospective purchaser will need a deposit of at least two per cent of the purchase price. Eligibility for the program is limited to individuals with an individual income of less than $90,000 or to couples with a joint income of less than $120,000. The federal government will provide 40 per cent of the property's purchase price for a new-build home and up to 30 per cent of the purchase price for an existing home. The purchaser will pay the stamp duty and will arrange the mortgage for the remainder of the purchase price, but they will not require lenders mortgage insurance. While purchasers remain in the Help to Buy scheme, they should have lower repayments. The government won't charge rent, and the purchaser will not have to pay any interest to the government for its equity contribution. But the government will take a second mortgage over the property as security over its equity contribution. We know that there's considerable disparity between housing prices in different parts of the country. So property price caps for the scheme will differentiate between states and territories and between urban and regional areas and the rest of the state or territory. For example, the price cap in urban Victoria is $850,000 and for the rest of the state it is $750,000.

The purchaser will need to live in the home and not rent it out or use it as an investment property. They can't already own other land or property either in Australia or elsewhere, but they do not need to be a first home buyer. This is important because it means that people who have co-owned properties but then sold them—for example, as part of a divorce settlement, and we know that people who are divorced in middle to late life often struggle to buy property subsequent to that—will be able to access the program. When a participant sells the property, they will need to repay the government, subject to some provisions around improvements which I'll refer to shortly. If a person sells their dwelling for $1 million and the government has a 30 per cent equity stake, they will need to repay the government $300,000 upon settlement, even if the initial stake was less than that. This is unless the person has already bought some of the equity back from the government prior to the final sale of the property. There are stipulations in the legislation regarding compulsory buyback of the government's share if a participant's pay increases above the borrowing threshold.

There has been some debate as to whether or not this program will push up house prices. Many say that 40,000 homes is not nearly enough and, sadly, that is true. Most agree though that, given the relatively small number of homes in the program, it is unlikely that it will have any significant inflationary effect on house prices, although it's important to note that a substantially expanded scheme, should one be launched by the government, would materially boost demand for housing and therefore also boost house prices and, hence, could prove both inflationary and counterproductive.

It is my view that there is much to be done and that this program is, sadly, only a very small part of a very large puzzle of housing. But it is one that will have a significant impact on the lives of the more than 40,000 people who might otherwise have little to no chance of purchasing a home. I hear from those people in my electorate office every week. I talk to them on the streets of my electorate. I understand that Australians—most of us—share the great Australian dream of home ownership. That is something which has, for many, many people, including my constituents, become just a dream in recent years.

That's not to say that this program could not be better. The income thresholds of the scheme are probably too high. About 70 per cent of working singles earn less than $90,000 a year. That's a very significant proportion of the population. And 39 per cent of couples earn less than $120,000. This scheme shouldn't be available to people who are on above average incomes—people who have a good chance of purchasing a home anyway. It should be reserved for those people who have very little chance of doing so without assistance. Also the entry requirement of a two per cent deposit, rather than the five per cent suggested by experts like the Grattan Institute during the development of this policy, increases the risk of borrowers falling into negative equity should house prices fail.

I've spoken before in this place about the critical need to maintain faith in our democratic institutions and the important role, the vital role, that parliamentary oversight plays in maintaining transparency. It's disappointing that yet again with this legislation we hear that most of its detail will be buried in the delegated regulations—in this case, the so-called program directions. Much of the program's detail remains unclear. For example, what happens if the value of the home declines? Granted that's unlikely in the current environment, but who will bear the cost should that happen? What about the cost of improvements to the home which increase its value? I'm informed that the program directions will contain a carve-out for renovations, such that the government's equity interest will not share in those benefits, but aren't these the kinds of complicated details we should see in the primary legislation? Wouldn't it be useful to have those program directions now with the main part of the legislation as we vote on the bill?

The speaker before me, the member for Makin, said that we can leave it to the government, that we can trust the government. But we're here for a reason, and that is to provide oversight over important allocations. This is a $25 billion scheme. We deserve to know the details of it and to have a chance to examine those details at the appropriate time, which is now. Moreover, yet again, we see that the program directions contained in the regulations are not disallowable. We can't dispute them, and they are not subject to sunsetting provisions. My crossbench colleague the member for Wentworth will propose that this be amended, and I will support her amendment. We need to enhance oversight, not diminish it, and in doing so, we need to avoid the cynical political manipulation that can occur or can be perceived to occur when important decisions are made behind closed doors. Transparency matters and, with an expensive, important scheme like this, the parliament and the people deserve transparency and clarity regarding process and policy.

This is a big step towards helping some Australians who are struggling. It remains to be seen if the shared-equity model adopted in this bill will be further developed or will remain limited to its current form, but what is certain is that it is past time that this government took substantial long-term action to fix a housing crisis which has been decades in the making. Politics shouldn't be about the next election. It should be about the next generation. For too long, Australian governments have thought more about their own future and less about the future of the country when it comes to housing. I'm glad we're taking action on this. It has to change.
I commend this bill to the House.

Ms ROBERTS (Pearce) (20:52): I'm incredibly pleased to rise in support of the Help to Buy Bill 2023, as I know what a difference a scheme like this can make for those wanting their own home. In my home state of Western Australia, Keystart, a shared-equity program, commenced in 1989 as an initiative of the WA state government. Keystart is a private organisation with one shareholder, the housing authority, and it continues today, having received the support of successive state governments. Keystart has helped more than 85,000 Western Australians become homeowners. It is designed to assist low- to moderate-income earners purchase a share in a home with the WA department of housing co-owning the property, with an up to 40 per cent share, depending on the buyer's income and household size. Later, when the buyer can afford to, they have the opportunity to purchase all of the department of housing share in the property so they own it outright. From my experience, the success of Keystart has had a lot to do with the fact that the buyer has some skin in the game and their ownership gives them a sense of pride and purpose. They know they won't get another chance, so their resilience and determination are reflected in the lower-than-average rates of arrears experienced by Keystart.

The door to homeownership should be open to my constituents in the Pearce electorate. I want them to be able to fulfil their dreams of owning their own home, which is exactly what the Help to Buy scheme will deliver. The Help to Buy shared-equity scheme is simply the government sharing the cost of the home. The government is not a co-owner. If you take part, it's yours, and, thanks to Labor, you achieve it with a low deposit and lower ongoing repayments. Let me point out again to the members opposite that help to buy shared equity is simply the government sharing the cost of the home. The government is not a co-owner. If you take part, this is your home, and, thanks to Labor, you will achieve this with a lower deposit and lower ongoing repayments.

I am aware of the importance placed on homeownership by local residents, especially by those approaching their retirement and likely to be relying on the pension for income in their later years. For some, owning their own home can be the difference between having a meal on the table or, indeed, a roof over their head. Financial wellbeing is essential for all of us, and many relate that to ensuring they have a home to live in. The 2021 census painted a rather disturbing picture in the Pearce electorate, given that 400 people identified themselves as homeless, with a hundred of those people being school-age children. Women aged 50-plus have, disturbingly, also found themselves among the homeless, despite still having earning capacity. It is important that they also have a pathway to owning their own home. It is imperative that we improve financial literacy and wellbeing in our communities. Becoming a homeowner means you need to understand what it means to have a mortgage and understand personal debt limits and savings programs. Talking to young people, I understand that the biggest barrier to homeownership is saving for a deposit for a house on a low or medium income. Sadly, for many the reality of homeownership appears to be nothing more than a pipedream, and this needs to change.

We acknowledge that it will take more than one measure to bring homeownership back into reach for many people, so we are committed to the Regional First Home Buyer Guarantee, which has already helped more than 13,000 people across Australia achieve homeownership. We also need more homes on the market, which is why we made the $3 billion New Homes Bonus available to the states to help them build more. Help to Buy will assist Australians both to overcome the hurdle of saving for a deposit and to service a mortgage. Through Help to Buy, the Commonwealth will cut the cost of buying a home by up to 40 per cent. Participants will only require a minimum two per cent deposit and will benefit from lower ongoing mortgage repayments through a smaller home loan.

The Help to Buy scheme is an important part of our government's housing reform agenda. The Albanese Labor government is also working with all states and territories to deliver a better deal for renters. This will include developing a nationally consistent policy to implement a requirement for genuine reasonable grounds for eviction; moving towards limiting rental increases to once a year; ensuring victims of domestic and family violence have the support they need to secure a safe and affordable home; considering options for better regulation of short-stay residential accommodation; and phasing in minimal rental standards. This is welcome news for the estimated 271,800 plus renters in WA. The maximum rate of Commonwealth rent assistance was increased by 15 per cent, the biggest increase in 30 years. This will help over 107,000 households in WA. Our government is offering new incentives to boost the supply of rental housing in WA by changing arrangements for investments in build-to-rent accommodation.

The Albanese Labor government has delivered $10 billion for the Housing Australia Future Fund, an investment to support social and affordable housing. In WA this includes 4,000 homes for women and children impacted by family and domestic violence or older women at risk of homelessness. The fund will help address acute housing needs within the first five years. There will be $200 million for repairs, maintenance and improvements to housing in remote Indigenous communities, $100 million for crisis and transitional housing options for women and children impacted by family and domestic violence and older women at risk of homelessness, and $30 million to build housing for veterans who are experiencing homelessness or at risk of homelessness.
Since the 2022 federal election we have held more than a hundred thousand people into homeownership through the Home Guarantee Scheme.

The Albanese Labor government has been working carefully on the design of the Help to Buy scheme with states, territories and lenders. Members opposite need to know that this is unlike the HomeBuilder scheme, which negatively impacted the housing market and was criticised by the states and territories. States will need to pass legislation for the Help to Buy scheme to operate in their jurisdiction, and the Western Australian government has agreed at National Cabinet to progress legislation so that the Help to Buy scheme can run in WA.

Help to Buy will support up to 40,000 low- and middle-income families across the country to purchase a home of their own. Housing Australia will deliver Help to Buy, and this scheme will help my residents in Pearce overcome the hurdle of both saving for their deposit and servicing their mortgage. This will be the first national shared-equity scheme of its kind. Through Help to Buy, the Commonwealth will cut the cost of buying a home by up to 40 per cent for new homes and 30 per cent for existing homes.

How disappointing it is that the Liberals are now delaying this scheme, hooking up with the Greens to string this along and continue to lock low- and middle-income earners out of their own home. Those opposite need to stop standing in the way of vital new assistance to help renters into secure homeownership. Owning your own home is something we all aspire to. I don't think you forget the day the build is finished or the sold sign goes up and you're handed the keys for the very first time. There is something special about knowing it is yours, that you can't be evicted by a landlord and that, if there are any changes you wish to make, you can make your own decisions freely without reference to another for approval. You can make the home your own and take pride in it. Ownership brings about a sense of security and belonging, embedding you in the community that you have joined. For older Australians, that security becomes very real when they're retired and are likely to be living on the age pension. I have spoken to many retired residents in Pearce who own their own homes and who have indicated the importance and positive impact that this has had on their financial and overall wellbeing. We want every Australian to have the security of having a roof over their head and a dignified retirement.

For residents still striving to gain homeownership, the new Help to Buy scheme is designed to make that goal easier to obtain. Importantly, Help to Buy will be open to assist residents who have owned homes before and those who haven't. Whether you be a single person, a couple, someone close to retirement or someone just starting out, Help to Buy can assist you. By providing equity contributions to eligible participants, the scheme will reduce the deposit required and lower their ongoing mortgage repayments, thus enabling low- to middle-income earners who enter the program to access housing. By improving access to homeownership and safe shelter, this bill provides the conditions for people to live a healthy life through alleviating the physical and mental stress associated with housing and rental affordability.

In an electorate like Pearce, which continues to grow—it's one of the largest and fastest growing in Australia—it is clear to see by the number of land developments underway that the goal of homeownership is still something we all aspire to, although it has been out of reach for some in our community. We have listened to the community, and we have acted. The Albanese Labor government's housing reform agenda will assist more homebuyers and renters. We want more Australians to have the door to homeownership opened to them. By delivering Help to Buy, along with our housing reform agenda, we will help more Australians achieve a safe place that they can call their home—their very own home. I commend this bill to the House.

Mrs McINTOSH (Lindsay) (21:03): It's five past nine at night, and Labor promised we wouldn't sit late in a new family-friendly parliament, but what's truth to Labor? It's lie after lie. Here we are, and I'm rising to speak on the Help to Buy Bill 2023 and its consequential provisions bill. The bills before the House aim to assist the very long-shot build of 1.2 million additional homes over the next five years. Good luck to the Albanese government on that target! To be frank, I don't see how this can even eventuate when the Labor government in my home state of New South Wales has conceded they can't reach the 75,000 new-build target each year over the next five years. I don't know how one government in one Labor state can say that they can't reach the target and the federal government can say, 'We're going to build 1.2 million additional homes.'

From the outset, I will note the opposition's disapproval of the bill before the House. It is a tick-and-flick bill so the housing minister can say she's achieved an election commitment by putting this legislation through the parliament but the states and territories still need to get on board. We need to support first home buyers with assistance, but a shared-equity scheme where the government owns part of your home is not the way to get housing supply moving back to where it needs to be. We have states that are lagging behind on housing targets due to aspects of red tape and never-ending changes to strategic initiatives. Of course we want our cities to have more housing and different housing stock that suits the lives of all residents but we need to get on with building homes and stop continuously talking about review after review.

Housing pressures are taking an immense toll in my community of Lindsay, which includes Emu Heights, Colyton, Londonderry near the Hawkesbury, and the new Western Sydney international airport at Luddenham. We are the heart of Western Sydney. We bridge the north and the south. Western Sydney is facing the brunt of the housing crisis. We're at the coalface of constant new developments popping up throughout our region without the additional infrastructure to support new residents in our community. We could have had that infrastructure, but $5 billion has been ripped away by this government.

Glenvale Park, in my electorate of Lindsay—older parts of the suburb were built 20 years ago. Now developers are building other parts and sections. We have had the Mulgoa Road ripped away as part of the $5 billion. It's extraordinary. This is a road that would have unlocked additional lanes to support traffic flow at three intersections along the corridor. Just getting off the M4 coming home from Penrith should take only minutes to get to Glenmore Park, Regentville, Jamisontown and South Penrith. Instead, the constant logjams of cars, buses and trucks create ongoing traffic issues. How can the Albanese Labor government be taken seriously when they want 1.2 million more homes but will not assist in providing the much-needed infrastructure to go alongside the increase in population?

We see this time and time again. Coalition governments build things. Labor gets re-elected, floats some big ideas and cuts what communities need most: infrastructure. We see this at the Commonwealth level, where Western Sydney, as I said, has had that $5 billion ripped away by Minister Catherine King. How can Western Sydney keep up with another housing boom when the feds won't come to the table on infrastructure and transport funding? They have cut St Marys and Kingswood commuter car park upgrades. People in my community need this. I wonder whether mums and dads who need to get straight into the car at night to take their kids to sport or pick them up after school are going to park when the neighbourhood is pumped with more development. The T1 heavy rail line is already well over capacity going from the Blue Mountains through Western Sydney and into the CBD. Will the Albanese Labor government assist in upscaling capacity of the rail network to support housing growth? We already know the state Labor Minns government has cut metro line extensions from the new airport to other parts of Western Sydney. Housing in south-western Sydney will go ahead as the aerotropolis kicks off, but yet again—typical Labor—they're cutting transport infrastructure in communities with growing housing needs.

Labor comes in here want to talk a big game on cars and driving down emissions, but they won't assist in fixing existing public transport infrastructure to take cars off roads in corridors were more housing is taking place. Where are the federal government's plans to further support the new airport and its advanced manufacturing, research, higher education and health precinct with more funding into the Metros? That's right: it just doesn't exist, but they're happy to keep ticking a box on housing targets without thinking about the future of our communities and what they will need to flourish.

Let's take a step back and remember what the Labor Party's commitment was on housing at the last election. They said they would get legislation through parliament to have Help to Buy up and running by 1 January 2023. However, we have the Help to Buy Bill before the House right now, and it's actually February 2024. I noted in my contribution to a housing motion moved by the member for Hughes yesterday that it looks likely to be an election year. It is quite possible, with the Albanese Labor government limping to the finish line. In their list of achievements, they want to sell to the Australian people that they have tried with housing by bringing Help to Buy before the parliament. Just trying is okay! But we know that if the bills pass this House and the Senate the scheme won't come online until the next financial year. If the bill passes, the housing minister will say on the hustings that they passed the bill and went ahead with the legislation. 'We're doing great!' But the minister will then pull the 'sorry, we ran out of time' card if there's insufficient data to demonstrate any positive benefit to any Australians, and particularly to young people trying to get ahead.

What the Labor Party forgot to mention at the 2022 election was that all states and territories need to legislate the scheme as well. I doubt this will happen in time to create the change the government wants to sell at the next election. The Labor Party went to the last election with this scheme in mind, despite most states already having a shared-equity scheme for potential homeowners to partake in. Victoria has the Homebuyer Fund, South Australia has the Home Start shared-equity option—they've all got extraordinary names—and Tasmania has the My Home shared-equity program. Where I represent, in New South Wales, there's the Shared Equity Home Buyer Helper scheme. The shadow housing minister has noted that in New South Wales, an extraordinary 94 per cent of places for the scheme have not been taken up. Maybe that's because Australians don't want the government owning part of their family home.

What I do know is that Aussies want a government that has the courage to put in place policies that will give first home buyers a real go at attaining the Australian dream—they want that dream for themselves, not to share it with the government—and to provide housing for those most in need. The previous coalition government did this work, and it was ably led by the honourable member for Deakin. He continues as our shadow housing minister because he has put in the hard yards, he understands the sector and he is passionate about Australians taking the first step to secure their family home. The National Housing Finance and Investment Corporation, which the coalition established, provided $2.9 billion-plus in low-cost loans that helped to support over 15,000 social and affordable dwellings across the country. I previously worked in the community housing sector, and I know that policies such as this really help providers to build homes for those in our community who just need that hand up.

I'm informed that we're seeing one in three first home buyers being supported by the coalition's Home Guarantee Scheme. This scheme helps Australians with deposits as low as two per cent to get assistance to enter the home they need. Saving for a deposit is getting harder and harder for young people, but the coalition's First Home Super Saver Scheme helps tens of thousands of Aussie families accelerate their deposit. Former prime minister Morrison noted the previous government's economic support during COVID in his valedictory speech today. The then government assisted the housing and construction sector during this time, with funds to allow 137,000 home builder applications. This generated $120 billion of economic activity and helped the sector survive the aftermath of multiple lockdowns across Australia.

It's a pity that under this Labor government we see the lowest levels of dwelling construction in over a decade. The forecast for national new home builds and renovation activity is slowing as well. And they want us to think that everything is going great! With a housing minister missing in action and the government's key piece of housing policy being introduced in the last part of this parliamentary term, no wonder we're seeing record high numbers of liquidations in the building and construction sectors. Compounding this is a shortage of available construction materials and their increased cost. And we have a Treasurer who has tried to take credit for the success of the coalition's schemes and reforms, which is just absolutely ludicrous.

The bills before us outline a niche scheme to help just 10,000 households each year. We need to boost aspiration in our country: providing families with an option from the government to own up to 40 per cent of their homes is not aspiration. We need an economy that ensures people can get on the property ladder without government overreach. The Labor government's proposal would see 10,000 households get access to Help to Buy each financial year and cost the Commonwealth $5.5 billion. I know where that $5 billion would have been better spent; it would have been better spent on the infrastructure in Western Sydney that has been ripped away. Shared-equity schemes across the nation have massive numbers of places remaining. This means that shared-equity schemes are currently not what Australians want to help them get the home they need for their family. The Albanese Labor government should go back to the drawing board and work out a serious plan to assist those who want to own their own home.

Mr BURNELL (Spence) (21:15): 'The house of every one is to him as his castle and fortress as well for his defence against injury and violence.' These words were penned back in 1604 by Sir Edward Coke. In the years that have since passed, these famous words have been repurposed many a time. They have perhaps diverged from their original intended meaning, but I would argue that contemporary adaptations have assisted their longevity, simplifying them to: 'A man's home is his castle.' It even became the premise behind the movie The Castle, a true Aussie classic, one ahead of its time.

Today it has become impossible for many Australians to understand what it is like to own a home. There is no aspirational class—it's a prize that has become unattainable by any realistic or objective standard. This is a problem that warrants a solution brokered between governments of all levels. According to the Grattan Institute, between 1981 and 2016 homeownership rates among the 25- to 34-year-old demographic fell from more than 60 per cent to just 45 per cent. However, this problem compounds further for the poorest 40 per cent of that cohort, with homeownership rates decimated during that time, falling from 57 per cent all the way down to 28 per cent—it has more than halved. This further highlights that this policy failure didn't occur merely today or yesterday; it has been baking into our economy for many years now. It is a problem requiring solutions across federal, state and territory governments. As such, it has festered within our economy and our society, with no one solution being a silver bullet.

By a concerted effort across government, coordinated through the federal government, we can aspire to mitigate and reduce the prevalence of the problem and, on some accounts, minimise its impact too. This is what Labor aspired to do by bringing policies on housing reform to the Australian people at the last election, policies with depth and complexity. We had aspirations for the parliament to provide support for this and many more reforms we have sought to legislate for. We should be standing up for the aspiration of those with more modest ambitions. Those who aspire to have long-term stable housing and a roof over their heads without periods of periodic impermanence are an aspirational class as well, and there are many out there in the community that fit that bill. That's why the Albanese Labor government has been taking a holistic approach to addressing housing policy on a number of fronts since taking office. Help to Buy is just one of those approaches. and it is one that I am proud to be speaking in favour of here today.

Help to Buy is a testament to the Albanese Labor government's commitment to addressing the challenges faced by so many Australians who are trying to carve out a slice of the Australian dream, Australians who are sick and tired of needing to justify to a bank how their rent payments provide proof of their ability to service mortgage repayments of a lesser amount. At its most basic and fundamental level, Help to Buy is a shared-equity scheme with 10,000 places per year to enable eligible applicants to purchase their first time. Through the scheme, the government will provide support by way of an equity contribution of 40 per cent for new builds and 30 per cent for the purchase of an existing home, all of this with a minimum deposit outlay of just two per cent. The scheme allows Housing Australia to enter into shared-equity arrangements with eligible homebuyers, effectively reducing the upfront deposit hurdle and ongoing mortgage repayments.

This initiative is a response to the escalating challenge many Australians face in saving sufficient funds for a deposit, exacerbated by rising housing costs and the increasing burden of mortgage repayments. The primary aspect of this legislation is its funding mechanism: the Commonwealth has mandated to provide Housing Australia with the necessary appropriations to make equity contributions on behalf of the government. The devil in the detail underpinning this legislation is one that is intrinsically designed to align with the Commonwealth's constitutional powers, leveraging the referral of powers from states under section 51(xxxvii) of the Constitution. This collaborative federal approach enables the scheme's nationwide application, accommodating the diverse housing markets and economic conditions across Australia's states and territories. Under this scheme, Housing Australia plays a central role, authorised to formulate, execute and monitor compliance with shared-equity arrangements. This encompasses the capability to terminate arrangements and manage noncompliance, ensuring the scheme's integrity and effectiveness.

The legislation also carefully considers the potential financial implications for the Commonwealth and aims to mitigate risks through strategic management and operational guidelines. The return on the Commonwealth's equity contributions is intricately linked to the property's value, ensuring that the government's investment is protected while supporting Australians' homeownership aspirations.

The Albanese Labor government's approach with the Help to Buy scheme is innovative yet pragmatic, designed to assist low- and middle-income earners in securing a stake in their own homes. It reflects a deep understanding of the barriers faced by prospective homeowners, including the significant hurdle of saving for a down payment amidst other cost-of-living pressures competing with this pursuit. The scheme represents the partnership between the government and the people. By providing an equity contribution, we aim to reduce the initial financial burden on individuals and families, making the goal of homeownership attainable for those who have been systematically disadvantaged by the current market conditions and are likely to have the disadvantage further ingrained as time moves forward.

This initiative is born out of a comprehensive dialogue with communities, financial experts and housing advocates. It is a response to the clear message from the Australian public that the status quo is untenable and a bold new direction is required. Help to Buy is a testament to what we can achieve when we come together with a common purpose, guided by principles of fairness, equity and responsibility. It's a reflection of our belief in the power of government to make a positive, tangible difference in the lives of those we serve. If that sounds somewhat vague and anyone needs a reminder of who that is, well, it's the Australian people.

This bill also represents a significant step towards rectifying the imbalances in our housing market, offering a practical, targeted solution that will open doors for many Australians. It is a carefully considered response to the complex issue of housing affordability, designed to complement existing measures and support a sustainable future for our housing market. By providing a pathway to homeownership for low- to middle-income earners, we are not just investing in property; we are investing in the dreams and aspirations of Australians, in the fabric of our communities and in the economic viability of our nation.

Help to Buy embodies a vision of an Australia where every citizen has the opportunity to own a piece of this beautiful country, an Australia where the basic dignity of having a place to call home is accessible, not just for a privileged few with the means to accumulate multiple runs on that particular board. The Help to Buy Bill 2023 is our commitment to that vision. It is a step towards rectifying the imbalance in our housing market and towards creating a more equitable and inclusive society. It is an investment in the future of Australian families, in the stability of our communities and in the strength of our economy. The foundation stone upon which Help to Buy is built is that of an unwavering belief in the dignity of homeownership and stable living arrangements, and the significance of those things in the lives and dreams of most Australians. This bill is not merely about the bricks and mortar that form the walls of a house; it's about creating homes, fostering communities and building a future where every Australian has a stake in our society.

The challenges we face in housing affordability are not unique to our time, yet they demand innovative solutions that reflect Australia's economic and social realities. The gap between income growth and housing prices has widened to a chasm, leaving many Australians without a clear path to homeownership. It is here in this gap that the Help to Buy scheme seeks to make its mark by offering a practical, targeted solution that acknowledges the diversity of needs among aspiring homeowners. The Albanese Labor government may have gotten wages moving in the right direction again, but Help to Buy, complemented by a number of other housing reforms—not just by this government but by state and territory governments as well—created cooperatively alongside a federal framework, is needed to unstack the deck, something that many have consigned to the too-hard basket for far too long. Cooperative federalism isn't a mere buzzword, although, through both its literal and plain meaning, it is a necessary component to making homeownership a reality for those who may have considered the Australian dream closer to a nightmare many moons ago.

Moreover, the Help to Buy scheme is designed with a flexibility to adapt to the varying needs of Australians across this country. Whether it's for a young family looking to plant roots in a community, a single professional seeking stability and investment or older Australians downsizing into more manageable living spaces, this bill offers a pathway to homeownership that respects the individual circumstances of each buyer.

In crafting this legislation, we have drawn upon a wealth of evidence and international examples that demonstrate the efficacy of shared-equity homes in improving housing affordability and have even incorporated lessons much closer to home, with similar schemes operated by the states. Other shared-equity schemes across Australia aren't competing with one another. They complement each other and expand the ability to access such a scheme to even more Australians, and this can only be a good thing.

This is, of course, unless you're a member of the Liberal-National-Greens alliance that we have seen at many junctures of this 47th Parliament thus far. Many a time this strange marriage of convenience formed to then block the government, particularly in the other place, to make housing more accessible, more plentiful and more affordable for Australians. It is somewhat worth trying to ascertain the animus from both parties that caused these supposed political opposites to attract to one another.

We all know that, by way of the member for Griffith's article in the Jacobin that was tabled in this place quite helpfully by the Prime Minister last year, the Greens don't want Australians to have the chance to have a stable roof over their heads through our housing policies because they are afraid that doing so 'would demobilise the growing section of civil society that is justifiably angry about the degree of poverty and financial stress that exists in such a wealthy country'.

For those opposite, I suppose their reason for keeping people from affordable housing through Help to Buy or the Housing Australia Future Fund is less about politics and more for the sake of sport, perhaps. One would be led to believe that those opposite would see shelter listed upon the base of Maslow's hierarchy of needs only to disavow it due to it also including self-actualisation—a foreign trait for many and a trait that many appear incapable of attaining or exhibiting in healthy quantities. That rule of thumb was not followed when an ABC journalist asked one of them to vividly recount any events from their years in government.

I note the member for Sturt commented only yesterday about the HAFF legislation, lamenting the Greens' eventual role in it passing to form part of the Albanese Labor government's housing reform agenda. To the member for Sturt and his side of the chamber, I would recommend that they provide their support to Help to Buy. You have the power to divorce from this marriage of your own making. If it were one of yours that you were proud of, why would you hide it from your friends?

The Help to Buy Bill 2023 represents a significant legislative effort to address Australia's housing affordability crisis through shared equity. It's technical and operational nuances are carefully crafted to ensure that the scheme is sustainable, effective and capable of making a meaningful impact on Australians' ability to achieve homeownership. By leveraging Commonwealth and state collaboration, backed by a solid legislative and financial framework, the bill sets the stage for a transformative approach to housing policy in Australia.

The Help to Buy Bill 2023 is a positive step towards realising the Albanese Labor government's vision for Australia, a vision where our housing market more strongly resembles a traditional Australian dream and less like the Australian nightmare and a vision where thousands of Australians will now have a chance of homeownership, where they would otherwise have a chance charitably described as negligible at best. Help to Buy is a step forward in the right direction towards realising the Albanese Labor government's vision by legislating further mechanisms where homeownership becomes possible to those considered long lost in the battle to get a foot in the door to an ever-tightening property market.

We as a government are pushing the dial back towards where it should be, one that makes someone's first home an attainable and affordable reality, a reality where homeownership becomes accessible to those previously sidelined for the first time in several years. It is my hope that, through this debate, we can have 40,000 Australians with solid roofs over their heads because of us coming together to support this bill. I commend this bill to the House.

Dr HAINES (Indi) (21:29): For so many Australians, buying your first home is one of life's big moments. I'll never forget my first home—the thrill of being able to paint the walls apricot pink and the idea of putting up Laura Ashley floral wallpaper. I even had a crack at tiling the bathroom, and I quickly realised that I should stick to my day job. It was the 1980s. Owning a home is part of our national story. It gives us a sense of place and a sense of security.
